title: builtin `Copy` field checks hide supertrait unimplemented error

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
### Code

```Rust
struct Foo {
    a: String
}

impl Copy for Foo {}
```


### Current output

```Shell
error[E0204]: the trait `Copy` may not be implemented for this type
 --> src/lib.rs:5:15
  |
2 |     a: String
  |     --------- this field does not implement `Copy`
...
5 | impl Copy for Foo {}
  |               ^^^
```


### Desired output

```Shell
error[E0204]: the trait `Copy` may not be implemented for this type
 --> src/lib.rs:5:15
  |
2 |     a: String
  |     --------- this field does not implement `Copy`
...
5 | impl Copy for Foo {}
  |               ^^^

error[E0277]: the trait bound `Foo: Clone` is not satisfied
 --> src/lib.rs:5:6
  |
5 | impl Copy for Foo {}
  |      ^^^^ the trait `Clone` is not implemented for `Foo`
  |
note: required by a bound in `Copy`
 --> /rustc/d5a82bbd26e1ad8b7401f6a718a9c57c96905483/library/core/src/marker.rs:391:17
  |
  = note: required by this bound in `Copy`
help: consider annotating `Foo` with `#[derive(Clone)]`
  |
1 | #[derive(Clone)]
  |
```


### Rationale and extra context

The fact that a field doesn't implement `Copy` hides the fact that the supertrait `Clone` is not implemented for the self type. This is annoying as once I fix the "field not copy" I have to then go and rerun the compiler to get the `Foo: Clone` error message that the compiler has known the whole time.

_No response_

### Anything else?

The suggested output for the supertrait not holding is suboptimal but I just copy pasted the existing output of the compiler and have filed a separate issue for that.
